TWDExtremals¶

extremals.TWDExtremals(data, bound=[-1, -1], keys=None, exclude=[], name='TWD')[source]¶

Applies a TWDTest on data

Parameters:
  • data – dataframe or series
  • bound (list) – list of two numbers following the same rules in OutOfBound, default [-1,-1]: no bound applied
  • keys (list) – list of columns to use, default None: all columns used
  • exclude (list) – list of columns to exclude, default empty
  • name (str) – name of the returned series, default 'TWD'
Return type:

pandas.Series

Examples:

data = ... # your dataframe
keys = ... # list of columns you are interesting in
twd_series = xt.TWDExtremals(data, keys = keys)

If one row x of data[keys] have values very far from the mean of the corresponding column then twd_series[x] will be higher than other rows. Moreover the contribution of each column is uniform, because of the normalization process used (see Normalize).

twd_series can also be obtained running any of the following commands

xt.TWDExtremals(data[keys])
xt.TWDTest(keys).Apply(data)
xt.TWDTest().Apply(data[keys])

Up to sorting the rows, the concatenation of data[key] and twd_series in one dataframe is obtained with

xt.AddTWDTest(data[keys])

Any of the following commands will gave us the 2% higher values of twd_series

xt.OutOfBound(twd_series, 0,0.02)
xt.TWDExtremals(data[keys], bound = [0,0.02])

Now consider the dataframe data

keys = ['col1', 'col3']
twd_series = xt.TWDExtremals(data[keys])

# twd_series is the last column of
    col1  col3       TWD
e    NaN  21.0  0.036613
i    9.0   NaN  0.083122
h    8.0   NaN  0.094124
l    0.0  21.0  0.218748
f    9.0   3.0  0.281877
g   22.0  -4.0  0.350183
a    3.0   0.0  0.387113
d   -3.0  44.0  0.552499
c    1.0 -13.4  0.584334
b  100.0  74.0  1.647650

Row b has values far away from the means and therefore its value on twd_series is higher.

extremals
